639798 Singapore School of Materials Science & Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798 ⁎ Corresponding authors. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) hydrodeoxygenation to 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) plays a significant role in biomass conversion. Herein, we develop a facile CoMo bimetallic catalyst with CoN4 single atom sites and low Co content (0.14 wt%) for this transformation which exhibits superior performance than most previous works (Turnover frequency up to 28.7 h−1, more than 8 cycles). A synergistic catalytic effect between Co and Mo sites are disclosed, in which the Mo sites mainly take part in the adsorption of substrates, while the Co sites mainly realize the adsorption and activation of H2. The mechanistic studies demonstrate that 5-methyl-2-furaldehyde (MF) is the main reason for the production of 1,2-bis(5-methylfuran-2-yl)ethane (BMF), and the hydrogenolysis of the aldehyde group is the slow step of this reaction. According to these insights into the mechanism, a two-step and one-pot process is firstly exploited for the HMF hydrodeoxygenation, resulting in a higher DMF yield under milder conditions. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Hydrodeoxygenation 2,5-dimethylfuran Single atom catalysis Bimetallic catalysis Data Availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The global energy demand has greatly increased with the rapid economic development, so a lot of efforts have been devoted to the field of renewable energy [1]. Among renewable energy sources, biomass energy is the only renewable organic carbon source, so it has the potential to replace non-renewable fossil resources to produce high value-added chemicals and fuels [2]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is one of the most important biomass-based platform compound, which can be prepared from fructose, [3] glucose, [4] and sucrose [5] by hydrolysis. A series of high value-added fine chemicals can be synthesized from HMF after oxidation, hydrodeoxygenation, hydrolysis and other transformations [6–10]. Among them, 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is considered to be one of the most potential new fuels due to its high energy density (31.5 MJ/L) and high octane number of 109, [11–14] meanwhile it can also be converted to various valuable chemicals [15]. Currently, high-efficiency conversion of HMF to DMF can be achieved by noble metal-based catalysts such as Pd, [16] Ru, [17] Pt, [18] and Ir [19]. Hu et al. have investigated the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process of HMF over Ru/C catalysts in THF at 200 °C for 2 h, obtaining 100 % HMF conversion and 94.7 % DMF yield [20]. Ordomsky’s group reported a novel supported metal bifunctional catalyst designed by pretreatment of the supported palladium catalyst with bromobenzene. The close relationship between the metal and acid functional groups in this catalyst results in unique catalytic performance on the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran, which can be achieved at ambient temperature and 5 bar H2, leading to 96 % yield of DMF [21]. Nevertheless, their large-scale application is hindered by the high cost of noble metals. In order to reduce the cost, a series of non-noble metal-based catalysts have been developed as the alternatives [22–27]. For example, a series of Co-based catalysts have been introduced for this transformation owing to its excellent ability for hydrogenation activation and Lewis acidity [28]. Zhang’s group reported that the mix phase ZrO2 supported Co catalyst with synergistic effect achieved the better yield of DMF than single phase ZrO2 supported Co catalysts [29]. Dong’s team prepared a β-Mo2C embedded carbon material, which could achieved a high 2,5-DMF yield of 91.6 % by the HDO of 5-HMF with ethanol as a hydrogen donor [30]. The issues of most non-precious metal catalysts are the long reaction time, harsh conditions and high catalyst dosage and poor recyclability. Hence, we wish to develop a new and efficient non-noble metal catalyst for this transformation to eliminate the above problems. Because the single metal atomization in heterogeneous catalysts can effectively improve the utilization of metal and catalytic performance per metal atom, the introduction of single metal atom catalysts in HDO of HMF may fruitfully minimize the amount of metal catalysts to be used [31–37]. Meanwhile, HDO is a complex multi-step reaction process, which is usually achieved by multi-site synergistic catalysis. Bimetallic catalysis is a classical strategy for accelerating the HDO process, in which one metal is used to activate H2 and the other metal can regulate the adsorption capacity of oxygen species [38–41]. Although Mo has a weak ability to activate H2, but its ability to adsorb oxygen species is very strong, so the main role of Mo in bimetallic catalysts is the enhancement of oxygen species absorption during the HDO reaction [42–45]. Furthermore, porous carbon materials are widely used as industrial adsorbents and catalyst supports due to their high surface area, large pore volume, good chemical inertness and thermal stability [6,8,46,47]. In recent years, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have attracted increasing attention of researchers due to their high specific surface area, ordered and tunable pore structure, simple synthesis method and high nitrogen content, which can be used as an ideal precursor for the synthesis of porous N-doped carbon materials [48–55]. Along this line, we have developed an efficient ZIF-derived nitrogen-doped carbon supported CoMo bimetallic catalyst for HDO of HMF to DMF. This material with CoN4 single atom sites and low Co content (0.14 wt%) exhibits superior catalytic activity over most previous works (Table S1). A synergistic catalytic effect between Co and Mo sites are disclosed, in which the Mo sites mainly take part in the adsorption of substrates, while the Co sites mainly realize the adsorption and activation of H2. A detailed study of the reaction pathway revealed that the HDO of the aldehyde group is the slow step, and 5-methyl-2-furaldehyde (MF) is the main reason for the production of 1,2-bis(5-methylfuran-2-yl)ethane (BMF, the main side product). Furthermore, we develop a two-step and one-pot process, in which furan-2,5-diyldimethanol (BHMF) is first afforded through a borrowing hydrogen strategy, which can be converted to DMF with 97 % yield under milder conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Characterization All chemical reagents are obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. GC-MS analyses are performed on an ISQ Trace 1300 in the electron ionization (EI) mode. The aliquot (1 μL) of resulting solutions was vaporized at 200 °C upon injection and the separation was programmed into two stages: [1] ramping up (5 °C/min) to 120 °C from the initial temperature of 40 °C after 5 min of equilibration, then [2] ramping up (10 °C/ min) to 260 °C from stage [1] after 2 min of equilibration. Finally, the sample would reach the FID detector for complete combustion. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded using a PHILIPS Tecnai 12 microscope operating at 120 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer, using an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV of photons) and calibrated by setting the C 1 s peak to 284.80 eV. During the XPS fitting process, all the FWHM parameters are controlled between 1 and 1.5. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was analyzed on an Optima 7300 DV. The BET surface area and pore size measurements were performed with N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Before measurements, the samples were degassed at 80 °C for 12 h. The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra (Fe K-edge) were collected at BL14W beamline in Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). The storage rings of SSRF was operated at 3.5 GeV with a stable current of 200 mA. Using Si(111) double-crystal monochromator, the data collection were carried out in fluorescence mode using Lytle detector. All spectra were collected in ambient conditions. The HAADF-STEM and EDX-mapping analysis were performed on Titan ETEM Themis. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 The synthesis of ZIFs Taking CoMo1@ZIF (1 means the molar ratio of Mo/Co) as an example, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.19 g, 4 mmol), Na2MoO4·2H2O (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.058 g 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL deionized (DI) water for sonication (Solution A). 2-Methylimidazole (1.314 g, 16 mmol) and aniline (1.5 g, 16 mmol) were dissolved in another 40 mL of DI water under ultrasonication (Solution B). Then, Solution A was gradually added to Solution B at room temperature and stirred for 12 h to yield CoMo1@ZIF, which was separated by centrifugation, washed by water, and dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h. Other ZIFs were prepared by the same method except that the amount of metal salt varies. The usage amount of metal salts for the synthesis of ZIFs have been listed in Table 1. 2.2.2 The synthesis of CoMox@NC Taking CoMo1@NC as an example, the pyrolysis of CoMo1@ZIF was carried out in a tube furnace under nitrogen atmosphere. The sample was calcined at 900 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min to obtain CoMo1@NC. Co@NC, Mo@NC, CoMo2@NC, CoMo0.5@NC and NC were prepared by the same procedure, except for using Co@ZIF, Mo@ZIF, CoMo2@ZIF CoMo0.5@ZIF, ZIF-8 as precursaors, respectively (Table 1). 2.3 The general procedures for the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF A 30 mL autoclave was charged with 0.48 mmol (0.06 g) HMF, 10 mL of reaction solvent, and 50 mg of catalyst. Then, the H2 pressure of this autoclave was increase to 1.5 MPa at room temperature. The reaction was heated to 170 °C, and continued for a certain time. The catalyst was separated through filtration, and the resulted filtrate is analyzed by GC and GC-MS to determine the reaction conversion and selectivity (Fig. S1). 2.4 Two-step, one-pot process for the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF In the first step, 0.48 mmol of HMF, 25 mg of nano Al2O3 (average particle size 20 nm) and 10 mL of n-propanol were added to an autoclave, and the reaction was carried out at 170 °C under 0.5 MPa Ar atmosphere for 4 h. In the second step, 25 mg of CoMo1@NC was added to the reaction mixture, and the reaction is further performed at 170 °C under 1.5 MPa hydrogen atmosphere for 6 h. The catalyst was separated through filtration, and the resulted filtrate is analyzed by GC and GC-MS to determine the reaction conversion and selectivity. The commercial nano Al2O3 needed to be washed with NaOH (1 M) solution and water to remove impurities on its surface before use. 2.5 Catalyst recovery After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with 3 mL methanol for three times, dried under vacuum to remove residual solvent, and the dried solid catalyst was reused directly in the next run. 2.6 Theoretical calculation methods All first-principles calculations were carried out using CASTEP module of the Materials Studio software (Accelrys Inc.). Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional approximation was selected as the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) method to calculate the exchange-correlation energy [56]. Ultrasoft pseudopotentials was used to simulate electron-ion interaction [57]. To account van der Waals correction, the TS (Tkatchenko, A.; Scheffler) DFT-D correction has been utilized for van der Waals dispersion corections [58]. The energy cutoff was set to 340 eV. Spin polarized is considered during the calculation. The k-point was set as 1 × 2 × 1. The optimization was completed when the energy, maximum force, maximum stress and maximum displacement were smaller than 1.0 × 10−5 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/Å, 0.05 GPa and 0.001 Å, respectively. During simulations, CoN4 model inset in C (001) surface was built with N:C nearly to 0.06 based on above experimental results. The adsorption positions OC, HO-C of C6H10O3 were considered. The adsorption energy (Ea) can be calculated by Eq. [1]. (1) E a = E a d s + s u r f a c e − E a d s − E s u r f a c e where Eads+surface is the total energy of the system, including the C6H10O3 and the facet after optimization; Eads is the energy of adsorb after optimization; Esurface is the energy of facets after optimization. In the definitions, the lower value of Ea indicates a more stable adsorption on the plane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations There are two peaks appear at about 24° and 44° in all the X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns, which can be indexed to the (002) and (100)/(101) crystal planes of carbon ( Fig. 1a) [31]. Two peaks at 35.7° and 62.8° can be observed in both XRD patterns of CoMo1@NC and Mo@NC, corresponding to the features of MoC(111) and MoC(200) (PDF#89–2868) planes [30]. No cobalt signal was observed in the XRD pattern of CoMo1@NC, ruling out the presence of large crystalline cobalt nanoparticles. The electronic structure and chemical state of CoMo1@NC were investigated by XPS spectroscopy (Fig. S2). There are four main types of nitrogen: pyridinic-N (398.2 eV), M-Nx (M = Co or Mo) (399.2 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.0 eV), quaternary-N (400.8 eV) (Fig. S2a) [31]. Three peaks can be deconvoluted in the spectrum of Mo 3d region (Fig. S2b), indicating that Mo species exists in three oxidation states (+2, +4 and +6) on the surface of CoMo1@NC, which may originate from some unreduced molybdates and MoC (Fig. S2b). The signal of Co 2p is too weak to analyze the state of Co owing to the low Co content (Fig. S2c). According to the N 1s and Co 2p XPS spectra of CoMo1@NC and Co@NC (Fig. S2a and S2c), the electronic structure and chemical state of Co and N are basically the same. Therefore, the structures of Co sites in Co@NC should be similar with that in CoMo1@NC. The electronic and coordination structures of Co sites in CoMo1@NC were investigated by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). In comparison of reference samples including Co foil, CoO and CoPc, CoMo1@NC has almost the same absorption edge as CoO, indicating its Co oxidation state is close to + 2 (Fig. 1b). As shown in Fig. 1c, no peak belongs to the Co-Co and Co-Mo bond in the R space at 2.1 Å, confirming only Co single atoms are present in the catalyst, and there is no direct interaction between Co and Mo. In the Fourier transformed (FT) EXAFS of CoMo1@NC, the best curve fit clearly presents the main peak originating from the Co-N/O coordination (Fig. 1c). The crystal parameters of cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) were used as the model for the EXAFS fitting analysis by Artemis. The average coordination number of nitrogen atoms around the cobalt center is 4.3, and the error of the fit results is within a reasonable range (Fig. 1d, Table S2). Therefore, the chemical coordination configuration of Co atoms in CoMo1@NC can be understood as a planar four-coordinated Co-N4 structure that coordinates 1–2 O or N species up and down in the axial direction. According to the N 1 s XPS spectra of CoMo1@NC (Fig. S2a), the content of pyridine N is much higher than pyrrole N, so Co is more likely to coordinate with the pyridine N. As shown in Fig. 2a, the morphology of CoMo1@ZIF is nanosphere with uniform particle size distribution. According to Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images of CoMo1@ZIF, a microstructure composed of irregular carbon particles with a small amount of metal agglomeration was observed (Fig. 2b). The images of elemental mapping reveal that the N and Co elements have been homogeneously incorporated into the carbon material. It can be seen that a small amount of Mo species agglomerates (Fig. 2c, e), which is consistent with the XRD and TEM results. The porous properties of this material were investigated using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The BET surface area of CoMo1@NC is 685.4 m2/g, and the pore volume is 0.42 cm3/g (Fig. S3, Table S3). According to the ICP results, the contents of Co and Mo in CoMo1@NC are about 0.14 wt% and 1.30 wt% respectively (Table S4). Although a large discrepancy in the Co/Mo ratio in the final CoMo bimetallic catalysts compared with their addition amount in the preparation process is found based on ICP results (Table S4), the addition amount in the preparation process and the loading amount in the final catalyst increase linearly for the same metal (Co or Mo) (Fig. S4). 3.2 The synergistic catalytic effects of Co and Mo sites Initially, these catalysts were screened in the HDO of HMF at 170 °C under 2 MPa H2 for 8 h ( Table 2). CoMo1@NC affords a higher HMF conversion and DMF selectivity than Co@NC and Mo@NC (entries 1, 2, 5), suggesting there may be a synergistic effect between Co and Mo sites. The catalytic activity of CoMo1@NC is also much better than the mixture of Co@NC and Mo@NC (entries 3 vs 5). 50 mg of CoMo1@NC has similar Co and Mo contents with the mixture of Co@NC (25 mg) and Mo@NC (25 mg), so closer Co and Mo sites may be more conducive to play their synergistic catalytic effects. The XPS and TEM tests of catalysts with different Co/Mo ratio were performed (Fig. S2 and S5). It can be concluded that there is no obvious change in the distribution and electronic state of metal sites (Co and Mo) in these catalyst. Thus, the differences in activity of these catalysts are mainly due to the change in Co/Mo ratio, and CoMo1@NC displays the best catalytic activity than CoMo0.5@NC and CoMo2@NC (entries 4–6). NC derived from ZIF-8 has little catalytic effect on the HDO reaction (entry 7), meanwhile the DMF yield of Co@NC was much higher than that of Mo@NC (entries 1 vs 2), so Co is the main catalytic site of CoMo1@NC. NH3-TPD and H2-TPD tests were also carried out to figure out the roles of Co and Mo sites in the reaction ( Fig. 3). NH3-TPD can detect the number and strength of acid sites in these catalysts, which is proportional to the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for oxygen species [42–45,59,60]. The order of acid site’s number and strength is Mo@NC > CoMo1@NC > Co@NC (Fig. 3a). It can be concluded that the introduction of Mo can offer more acid sites than Co, thereby exhibiting better adsorption capacity for HMF. According to results in Table 2 and catalyst characterization data, both Co and Mo species are necessary for the reaction, which mainly exist in the form of CoN4 sites and MoC nanoparticles, so the adsorption energy of HMF on MoC(111) and CoN4 with different configurations (via the furan ring or the oxygenated pendant functions) have been calculated, and the optimized adsorption structure and the corresponding adsorption energies have be given in Fig. 4. According to DFT calculations, the adsorption energies of HMF on the surface of MoC(111) are much higher than that on CoN4 site, which further proves this conclusion. The H2-TPD tests suggest that the order of H2 adsorption capacity is Co@NC > CoMo1@NC > Mo@NC (Fig. 3b), so Co sites have better adsorption capacity for H2 than Mo [61]. Further combining with the fact that Co is the main catalytic site of CoMo1@NC, so we can conclude that the Co sites of CoMo1@NC mainly realizes the adsorption and activation of H2. The role of N-doped carbon (NC) in CoMo1@NC can be summarized into two aspects [1]. As a stabilizer for Co and Mo species, NC can effectively ensure their dispersion and uniformity [2]. NC provides a nano porous environment for catalytic reactions, which facilitates the interactions of metal active sites and substrates. 3.3 Catalytic performance The H2 pressure and temperature were also screened to further optimize the conditions ( Fig. 5). At lower H2 pressures and temperatures, the yield of DMF increases with the hydrogen pressure and temperature. Notably, a low yield of DMF (14 %) was also produced in the absence of H2. These results suggest that CoMo1@NC is not a good catalyst for hydrogen auto-transfer hydrodeoxygenation, and additional H2 is the main hydrogen source for the achievement of HMF hydrodeoxygenation. Both H2 and n-propanol are cheap chemicals, so it is also economical when both of them are used. When the temperature (170 °C) and H2 pressure (1.5 MPa) reach a certain level, the yield of DMF no longer increases (Fig. 5a and b). After screening of different solvents (THF, toluene and 1,4-dioxane), n-propanol provide the best results, presumably its hydrogen borrowing reduction ability. The recyclability and stability of the CoMo1@NC catalyst were studied under the optimized conditions (Fig. 5c). After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with MeOH, and then used directly for the next run. After 8 cycles, the conversion of HMF dropped from 100 % to 83 %, and the yield of DMF dropped by about 14 %. The used catalyst has been characterized by XRD, ICP, TEM and BET to investigate the reason for activity loss. The ICP results suggest that the change in metal content of the used catalysts is negligible (Table S4). According to the XRD and TEM results, the dispersion of Co and Mo remains basically unchanged (Fig. S6). The BET surface area of CoMo1@NC decreases sharply from 685.4 m2/g to 210.0 m2/g after 8 runs, which should be the main reason for the decrease in activity (Table S3, Fig. S3). 3.4 Mechanism of HMF hydrodeoxygenation 3.4.1 HDO reaction pathway HMF has both hydroxymethyl and aldehyde group, so that a series of products may be yielded during hydrodeoxygenation ( Fig. 6). In order to clarify the reaction process, we performed several reaction tracking experiments (Fig. 6a). A large amount of MF and 2-methyl-5-(propoxymethyl)furan (MPF) appeared at the early stage of the reaction, and gradually disappeared with the increase of reaction time, indicating that both two substances are the main intermediates in the reaction. The yield of BMF increases with the reaction time, so BMF is a side product of the reaction, whose structure is confirmed by GC-MS, 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Fig. S8) [26,62]. To determine the possible route to produce BMF in the catalytic system, several potential intermediates including BHMF, MF, (5-methylfuran-2-yl)methanol (MMF) were chosen as the starting materials for HDO reaction (Fig. 6b). BMF is only produced in the HDO of MF, further confirming BMF is mainly afforded from MF at the beginning of the reaction. Based on above results, the possible reaction pathway for the conversion of HMF to DMF was illustrated in Scheme 1. First, an important intermediate product MF is generated through the hydrogenolysis of the C-O bond of HMF. Then DMF is formed by hydrogenation and deoxygenation of MF’s aldehyde group. At the same time, (5-methylfuran-2-yl)methanol (MMF) can react with n-propanol to generate MPF. Then, DMF is afforded following the HDO of MPF. In addition, the side product BMF is obtained by the coupling of MF [26]. 3.4.2 Kinetic study To clarify the rate-determining steps of the reaction, kinetic experiments of HMF hydrodeoxygenation on CoMo1@NC were performed by measuring the initial reaction rate at conversion levels below 20 % at different H2 pressures and HMF concentrations. As shown in Fig. 7 (Table S5 and S6), the initial reaction rate shows an evolution trend that first increases to the maximum value and then decreases with the increase of the H2 pressure or HMF concentration. According to Hougen−Watson/Langmuir−Hinshelwood kinetic models, [63] the observed evolution of the initial reaction rate suggests that the rate-determining step of the reaction is not H2 dissociation, adsorption, or activation of HMF, but rather the reaction between activated H (metal hydrides) and the adsorbed substrate on the catalyst surface. Simultaneously, the parabolic trend of the initial reaction rate observed in the kinetic experiments also indicates that there may be competitive adsorption of H2 and HMF on both Co and Mo sites. This conclusion can explain the role of Mo in HDO reaction: Because HMF preferentially adsorbs on Mo sites instead of Co sites, [42–45,61] the introduction of Mo can reduce the amount of HMF adsorption on Co sites in the low concentration HMF solution, thereby weakening the competition adsorption on Co sites. The reaction tracking experiments were carried out at three different temperatures 423.15, 438.15 and 453.15 K to determine the kinetic parameters (Fig. S7a-S7c, Table S7). In all experiments, an excess of H2 (over 37 equiv.) compared to HMF was employed to assume a constant H2 concentration during HDO process. Therefore, a pseudo-first-order law model was applied to calculate the kinetic rate constants and activation energies. The proposed kinetic mechanism for the HDO of HMF is obtained using the set of derived ordinary differential equations, where k1, k2, k3, k4, k5, k6 and k7 are the pseudo-first-order rate constants for the hydrogenation of HMF at a certain reaction temperature (Scheme 1). No MMF is observed in these tracking experiments, so it is impossible to calculate all the rate constants k2-k5 and their corresponding activation energies Ea, and the magnitude of these parameters can only be judged qualitatively. In order to simplify the calculation process, we set the reaction rate constant of MF to DMF conversion as k7 (More details in Supporting Information). The activation energies and rate constants of these reactions were obtained according to Arrhenius equation ( Table 3 and Fig. S7d), both which display good linear relationship, verifying the justifiability of this reaction kinetic model. Therefore, the HDO of MF to DMF is a slower step than the HDO of HMF to MF in this HDO reaction, which is also consistent with literature conclusions [22]. The DFT calculation suggests that oxygen anion (-O-) has a stronger adsorption energy than -CHO in both CoN4 site and MoC(111), which also supports this conclusion (Fig. 4). The k6 of the side reaction is much smaller than k1 and k7, which proves the high selectivity of the target product. Also higher reaction rates are always observed at higher temperatures, which explains the higher yields at higher temperatures. 4 One-pot, two-step process for the HDO of HMF MF can produce a small amount of side product BMF in HDO reaction, which is the main reason for the decrease in the reaction selectivity. If the DMF selectivity in the reaction is to be improved, the formation of MF during the reaction must be avoided. A feasible strategy is to first selectively reduce HMF to BHMF through a borrowing hydrogen strategy, in which the reduction of HMF can be realized using alcohol as the hydrogen source [64,65]. Furthermore, the HDO of BHMF should be easier than the HDO of HMF since the HDO of MF to DMF is a slower step than the HDO of HMF to MF. Alone this line, a follow-up study of the two-step reaction for the HDO of HMF is performed. First, different catalysts were applied to convert HMF to BHMF under Ar atmosphere ( Table 4 and S5). Only trace of BHMF was obtained in the case of CoMo1@NC (entry 1). Commercial Al2O3 is chosen as the catalyst in view of its good catalytic activity on the borrowing hydrogen hydrogenation of aldehydes, which is originated from its simultaneous Lewis acid and base sites [65]. Nano Al2O3 could provide a better yield than Al2O3 owing to its smaller particle size, which exposes more Lewis acid and base sites (entries 2 and 3). In addition, the optimized reaction time was 4 h (Table S8). Next, different catalysts for second step were also screened (entries 3–6). Nano Al2O3 failed to yield DMF, and CoMo1@NC was the best option for this step. Finally, the reaction time of the step was also optimized, and a 92 % yield of DMF could be obtained in 2 h. It is worth noting that the yield of DMF can be higher than BHMF yield in some cases (entries 1, 3 and 7), because the by-product or unreacted HMF in the reaction of HMF to BHMF can be also converted to DMF (Table S8). 5 Conclusions In summary, a nitrogen-doped carbon supported CoMo bimetallic catalyst with CoN4 single atom sites has been fabricated by the pyrolysis of CoMo-doped ZIFs. This catalyst exhibits superior catalytic performance on the HDO of HMF to DMF (Turnover frequency up to 28.7 h−1, more than 8 cycles) than most abundant metal-based catalysts owing to the synergistic catalysis of Co and Mo sites. In this catalyst, Mo sites mainly take part in the adsorption of substrates, while alleviating the competition between H2 and substrate adsorption on Co sites, and Co sites mainly realizes the adsorption and activation of H2. Insights into the mechanism of this transformation have also been performed. The main reaction route is the HDO of the hydroxymethyl group of HMF to generate MF, which is converted to DMF following hydrogenation and HDO processes. The HDO of MF to HMF is the slow step, which results in the side product BMF, thereby limiting the DMF yield. To overcome this limitation, a two-step one-pot process has been disclosed, which can efficiently enhance the reaction rate and DMF yield. This chemistry not only provides a new and efficient catalyst for HDO of HMF to DMF, but also gains insights into the reaction mechanism, thereby opening a new avenue to synthesize DMF from HMF. coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) hydrodeoxygenation to 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) plays a significant role in biomass conversion. Herein, we develop a facile CoMo bimetallic catalyst with CoN4 single atom sites and low Co content (0.14 wt%) for this transformation which exhibits superior performance than most previous works (Turnover frequency up to 28.7 h−1, more than 8 cycles). A synergistic catalytic effect between Co and Mo sites are disclosed, in which the Mo sites mainly take part in the adsorption of substrates, while the Co sites mainly realize the adsorption and activation of H2. The mechanistic studies demonstrate that 5-methyl-2-furaldehyde (MF) is the main reason for the production of 1,2-bis(5-methylfuran-2-yl)ethane (BMF), and the hydrogenolysis of the aldehyde group is the slow step of this reaction. According to these insights into the mechanism, a two-step and one-pot process is firstly exploited for the HMF hydrodeoxygenation, resulting in a higher DMF yield under milder conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the route of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural hydrodeoxygenation to 2,5-dimethylfuran over N-doped carbon anchored CoMo bimetallic catalyst
